Voters don't choose their politicians so much these days as politicians choose their voters.
The combination of a partisan process in most states and increasingly sophisticated computer software allows politicians to redraw the lines of electoral districts to maximize their party's chances.
They lump as many of their opponents' voters as they can into two or three districts and then spread out their own supporters to give their candidates a nice safe cushion come Election Day.
Next Tuesday, Ohio and California will vote to reform redistricting laws.
The proposals are somewhat different, but both would take the power to draw the lines away from politicians and put it in the hands of independent bipartisan commissions.
The goal is to create competitive races and draw district maps that look more like squares and less like snakes.
The problems is that either of those goals is hard, and both may be impossible.
Later in the program we'll go to Pakistan, where there's a race with winter to provide shelter for millions left homeless by last month's earthquake.

In 2004, as everybody remembers, the presidential race in Ohio was pretty close.
In congressional races, Ohio selected 12 Republicans and six Democrats.

How is that possible in a state that's roughly 50-50?
Well, it is roughly 50-50.
There are--Bush beat Kerry here by only two points.
There are almost equal numbers of votes in the aggregate for the 18 congressional candidates, and the reason it's so lopsided is because the lines are gerrymandered to be lopsided.
There are 18 congressional districts in this state, and maybe four of them are competitive.
There are 33 state Senate districts, and probably five are competitive, and of the 99 Ohio House districts, it's generous to say that maybe 15 of them could be won by either party.
And who draws the district lines now?
Well, it's a panel called the state apportionment board, and it is comprised of two members from opposite parties of the General Assembly: the governor, the secretary of state and the state auditor.

And so the party that wins two of the three races for auditor or secretary of state and governor then controls the controlling board, which draws legislative districts and then the General Assembly draws congressional districts.
And in Ohio, the General Assembly and all of state government, in fact, has been controlled by Republicans overwhelmingly for the last 10 years.
And is it safe to say that the redistricting reform effort is supported largely by Democrats?
Yes, absolutely.
That's kind of the impetus.

I think there are five ballot issues on the Ohio ballot in November, November 8th, and they all kind of come out of the national partisan anger, I think, from 2004, but redistricting is the one that has drawn the most attention here.
And oddly enough, both sides in favor are the Democrats, and there are some good government groups, such as Common Cause and others, that have joined on.

And oddly enough, the opponents of Issue 4, the redistricting amendment, mostly Republicans and their allied business groups, admit that the way we draw districts now is unfair and needs to be reformed.
They just say that the current ballot remedy is the wrong remedy.

Dale Maharidge is now a professor at the Columbia University School of Journalism.

Hi, Dale.
Hi, how are you?

Well, it was a no-brainer.
I couldn't leave them there.

An old editor, Howard Simons, he was the editor of The Washington Post during the Watergate, once told me, you know, in order to be a first class journalist, you must first be a first class human being.
